data.title: Manchester City Annual Report 2010
data.meta_description: Manchester City Annual Report 2010 - Download as a PDF or view online for free

2. Message from the Chairman 01 Message from the CEO 03 Football Excellence 05 Fans 17 Community 35 Commercial and Operational Excellence 45 Financial Review 55 Financial Statements 57 Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 Contents

Message from the Chairman Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 Message from the Chairman 01/02

With all of this comes an obligation to deliver growth and development that can ultimately be commercially balanced and sustained. Improving our performance in each of these areas simultaneously is an ambitious strategy, and there is no denying that a transformation of this magnitude requires heavy up-front investment. In the 2009-10 financial year, the Club has reported a loss, while our commercial revenue has increased significantly. Message from the CEO Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 Message from the CEO 03/04

8. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 ONE. Football Excellence 11/12

9. City’s reserve, Under-21 and Academy teams who can now play in a more competitive atmosphere in newly-improved playing facilities. The Club has a duty of care to help players from many backgrounds integrate into life in Manchester socially, culturally and logistically Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 ONE. Football Excellence 13/14

10. 11. “ We shut off the floodlights and a hush fell over the crowd. We hadn’t told people what to expect and no-one had ever done anything like Manchester City’s ambition it before at a is to be a leading club in every football match. aspect of our performance. Then a giant In many cases, that’s a Blue Moon challenge that has required projection significant investment and appeared reform in recent years. inside the stadium and However, in one area Manchester City has always the fans began been at the top of the table. A decade after City to sing as it fans showed unstinting support to help the Club win promotion from the Second Division of the floated over Football League, new owner Sheikh Mansour them. The delivered a clear message to Manchester City hairs stood up supporters: “You are the greatest fans in the world.” on the back of “ City fans remain this club’s heritage and its future. my neck Respect for this legacy means that everyone at the Club – from the players to the ground staff - has a duty to deliver the best possible experience for the supporters. This is a responsibility that Andy Derbyshire, needs to be fulfilled throughout all of our touch Head of Match Day points with the fans, from the website, to the box and Events office, to inside the stadium on match days and even in the car parks. The newly introduced City Promise initiative sets out our key objectives for ensuring our fans and visitors enjoy a premium match day experience each time they visit the stadium, and has involved extensive investment in professional training for all of our match day employees. We have also established a dedicated match day and events team to ensure the experience for fans and visitors is as memorable as possible. Fans Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 TWO. Fans 17/18

Our retention rate among Seasoncard holders from 2009-10 was n The result of this segmentation work was that 92 percent, and even our lowest attended home the average adult Seasoncard price fell by game last season versus Blackburn attracted 7 percent from 2008-09 to 2009-10 while the more than 40,000 attendees. (home Premier League matches only) reached an n For the 2010-11 season, the number of impressive figure of 864,751 – or 96 percent of Seasoncards has been capped at 35,000 capacity - with the most attended game against and a waiting list is now in operation. Tottenham Hotspur in May 2010 attracting a capacity crowd of 47,370. Alongside a more accessible approach to ticketing and recently opened facilities at the stadium such as the new Family Stand and City Square fanzone, fans can expect a number of special events and surprises to enhance their match day experiences throughout the coming season. Our average attendance for Premier League home games in 2009-10 was 45,513, up 6.1 percent on the previous Manchester City Football Club season Annual Report 2009/10 TWO. Fans 21/22

14. Over the last two years, the Club has spent an average of £255 per Seasoncard holder on improvements to our fan related services and facilities The City Promise n The City Promise (see opposite) is the Club’s quality commitment to fans and visitors, which applies to the standards of our staff, facilities and all other aspects of the match day experience. n To help deliver on the City Promise, all of the Club’s 600 part-time match day employees have received professional training on all elements of the initiative. n Our match day staff have also been transitioned onto fixed term contracts, giving them a greater stake in the future of the Club and providing our fans and visitors with a more consistent experience. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 ™ TWO. Fans 23/24

15. Showing Your Support n Based on feedback from our fans, we have made significant improvements to the retail experience provided by the Club during 2009-10 by enhancing our digital offering, product ranges and distribution capabilities. n In the first year of our new kit supply partnership with Umbro, retail sales and merchandise revenue increased by 60 percent in 2009-10 to a total of £7.9m. n The most popular name printed on City shirts by the fans was leading goalscorer of the season Carlos Tevez. n Roberto Mancini inspired plenty of City fans of his own during the colder months of the year, with more than 12,000 of his trademark scarves sold during the season. City Square n The most dramatic supporter innovation for the current season has been the opening of City Square in August 2010, a spectacular new meeting place for fans designed to bring new life to a previously grey area adjacent to the stadium which has become a focal point for pre-match entertainment. n City Square includes a live entertainment venue with a capacity of 5,000, which can be used for live appearances by players and performers. n A new café and bar offer a range of food and drink options for fans and visitors to the stadium. n Interactive video screens with content provided by mcfc.co.uk and the Manchester City fan community will ensure City Square becomes an informative and entertaining space both before and after games. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 TWO. Fans 25/26

16. A Family Friendly Club Working With Our Fans n According to research the Club conducted in n Nobody understands what makes a match 2010, 97 percent of season ticket holders and day special more than City fans, which is why even 79 percent of non-fans consider MCFC we encourage all of the Club’s supporters to to be a family-friendly football club. share their ideas with us so we can help bring them to life. n We are proud of our reputation as a family- friendly club and have invested substantially n Fan consultations, conducted throughout 2009, to create a new Family Stand, which we have were involved with the development of the new doubled in size for the 2010/11 season. ticketing strategy for the 2010-11 season and the design of the new Family Stand. n Every aspect of the Family Stand’s design lets fans know that they are in a child-friendly n Before the 2009-10 season home kit launch area, to discourage bad language, which is with Umbro, fan group leaders were given a consistently highlighted as a concern by City preview of the designs and the first 5,000 fans supporters. to buy the shirt were invited to a free concert to celebrate the launch. n The stand is designed with the needs of children and families in mind – with lower n In July 2010, the Club and representatives refreshment serving points and specially from both organisations were instrumental designed bathroom facilities. in the unification of the two leading City supporter organisations - The Official Supporters n New menus have been introduced, with healthier Club (OSC) and the Centenary Supporters options and smaller portions for children. Association (CSA) - creating the new n Games and interactive displays throughout Manchester City Supporters Club (MCSC). the concourse will add a new dimension to the n The Manchester City Supporters Club has more entertainment before the game and at half time. than 100 branches across the world, with close to 10,000 members. The Club, in 2009, created a Blue Moon plaque to mark designated bars in cities across the world as the official gathering point for City fans. n Consultation through surveys, focus groups and the reading of supporter websites will continue to be a key source of advice for the Club in its ongoing efforts to meet and exceed the expectations of our supporters. We are proud of our reputation as a family- friendly club and have invested substantially to create a new Family Stand, which we have doubled in size for the 2010/11 season Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 TWO. Fans 27/28

19. We aim to Celebrating City Culture and Heritage celebrate the n We are proud of our heritage, loyal club n As a club with roots in the heart of Manchester, best of the servants and former players. The Club’s doors we aim to celebrate the best of the city’s culture city’s culture are always open to former players with many taking roles in our match day suites, or as and musical heritage and export the best of Manchester life around the world. and musical welcome guests. heritage and Most notably, the Club created a new position n The Club intends to continue its tradition, expanded during visits to cities as diverse export the best n of Club Ambassador, appointing our much loved as New York and Abu Dhabi, of hosting City- of Manchester 60s City legend Mike Summerbee to the role. styled barbeques and music events to give life around the n In March 2010, then Club Secretary Bernard our international fans an authentic taste of world Halford, in his 50th year in football was Mancunian culture and hospitality. announced as only the second Life President n To date a total of seven pubs and bars in of the Club in recognition of his outstanding various countries around the world have been contribution and continued commitment to branded as City supporter venues with our Manchester City. customary Blue Moon plaques in locations as diverse as Melbourne and Paris, Abu Dhabi n In 2010, two sets of former players were and New York. introduced to the crowd before matches. The first was the 1969-70 League Cup winning team n Throughout the 2009-10 season, the City ahead of our first leg Carling Cup Semi Final Buskers programme provided young local clash against Manchester United and later in artists with unprecedented opportunities the season, the 10th anniversary of the pivotal to perform outside the City of Manchester second division play off final against Gillingham Stadium on match days, gaining exposure was marked with fans responding warmly to the for their music and improving the match day key players from that remarkable day. experience for supporters. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 TWO. Fans 33/34

20. “ The City in the Community programme is an embodiment of the Club’s integrity and authenticity. We’ve always been about more than just photo opportunities and one-off events. We want all of our programmes to leave a lasting legacy on the individuals, organisations and communities “ we work with Sarah Lynch, Managing Director, CSR Community Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 THREE. Community 35/36

21. In 1880, Anna Connell, the minister’s daughter Throughout of St Mark’s Church, West Gorton, Manchester its history, decided to form a football team. Her mission was to give access to football for her community, MCFC has a community that was suffering from social maintained deprivation, resulting in high levels of a strong unemployment, alcoholism and violence. and lasting In 1894, the Club originally known as “St Mark’s” relationship evolved to become Manchester City, founded on with the a belief that football can create a greater sense of community and opportunity. And it is that belief people of that remains at the heart of the Club to this day. St Mark’s Church, West Gorton Manchester Throughout its history, MCFC has maintained a and its strong and lasting relationship with the people surrounding of Manchester and its surrounding areas. Our areas connection to the local community has always been central to the Club’s identity. Today, we are proud to remain a key institution in the community 1904 FA Cup Winners to which we belong, and one whose positive impact continues to grow. In the 2009-10 financial year, we have made significant investments in the flagship City in the Community programme, which next year will celebrate its 25th anniversary. Meanwhile, internal 1934 FA Cup Winners developments and new staff appointments have greatly expanded the potential of the Club to maximise its positive social, economic and community impact in the years ahead. In February 2010, we appointed a new Managing Director for Corporate Social Responsibility with significant international business experience to oversee and better coordinate the Club’s work in the following areas: 1. The City in the Community initiative, which has contributed significantly to the community of Manchester since 1986. Frank Swift - City goalkeeper 1933-1949 2. City in the Community Giving, a new programme designed to provide monetary grants to other not-for-profit organisations operating in the Greater Manchester area. 3. Responsible Corporate Citizenship, to ensure that MCFC contributes to the achievement of positive social, economic and environmental outcomes through all of our day-to-day operations. Our consultations with City fans have made it clear that our supporters expect their football club to take seriously its responsibility to the local community, and they are proud of the contributions their Club has made to date. As our City in the Community programme and broader CSR framework expands, we are committed to maintaining our reputation as an organisation that players, employees and fans alike are all proud to say they are a part of. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 THREE. Community 37/38

22. City in the Community n City in the Community (CITC) was founded in 1986, aiming to forge closer links between our Club and the local community. n With a team of 20 full time and 30 part time staff CITC runs projects based around four key areas: Sport, Health, Young People and Skills & Enterprise. n Every year our award winning team engages with over 200,000 people of all ages and across all communities over Manchester, Tameside and Stockport. n In the last year, more than 50,000 children participated in City in the Community’s free soccer schools. n Through staff donations and a contribution from the Club, MCFC provided the Manchester Children’s Hospital with a £500,000 donation for the establishment of a specially-designed children’s play area. In the n Through CITC, first team player and the last year, Club’s Enterprise Ambassador, Nigel De Jong, is helping young people from the Greater more than Manchester area develop enterprise and business skills to establish their own careers. 50,000 n More than 3,000 high school students have children gained an accreditation in business studies as a result of CITC’s enterprise programme, run participated in partnership with the Premier League. n City in the Community aims to expand the in City in the capacity of its sports programmes from 70,000 in 2009-10 to more than 80,000 in 2010-11 Community’s following the opening of new facilities in the SportCity complex. free soccer schools Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 THREE. Community 39/40

23. City in the Community Giving n Through CITC Giving, proactive local charities and not-for-profit organisations are invited to apply on an annual basis for the Club’s support for projects designed to have a lasting and positive impact on the Greater Manchester area. n City fans will choose from a shortlist of charities each year to identify the organisations the Club will support in the year ahead. n Once chosen, the Club will raise funds for selected charities and support them in other ways throughout the year. n Fans and staff are also encouraged to hold their own events in support of the winning organisations, with the Club providing support and publicity for these efforts through our own media channels. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 THREE. Community 41/42

24. In July City CSR Goes International 2010, MCFC n In July 2010, MCFC initiated the construction initiated the of a rooftop football pitch at the Lexington construction Academy school in Spanish Harlem, in partnership with the Embassy of the UAE in of a rooftop Washington, DC, marking the establishment of football a landmark programme to provide children in pitch at the New York with access to much-needed facilities Lexington and MCFC’s award-winning coaching and education programmes. New East Manchester Joint Development Board n In March 2010, MCFC, Manchester City Council and New East Manchester (NEM) signed a formal agreement to work together to create a transformation plan for East Manchester, focused on the area around the City of Manchester Stadium. n A Joint Development Board (JDB) has been formed between the three parties, which will combine Manchester City Council and NEM’s land ownership and experience in community Responsible Corporate Citizenship regeneration with MCFC’s commercial n MCFC recently formalised its Equal Opportunity relationships and history of investment in the Employment policy, acquiring Two Ticks Club’s development. accreditation for employees with disabilities. n The combined interests of the land held by the n MCFC’s carbon footprint was reduced by roughly three parties represents a total of around 200 30 percent between 2007-08 and 2008-09. acres, including the existing SportCity campus and 46 acres of land in Openshaw West owned n In mid-2009 MCFC established a sustainable by Manchester City Football Club. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 FOUR. Commercial and Operational Excellence 47/48

27. More than £1.5m has been spent in 2010 alone on improvements to the pitches in the City of Manchester Stadium and our training grounds at Carrington and Platt Lane New Infrastructure and Facilities n In July 2009, MCFC opened its new 1200m2 corporate offices adjacent to the City of Manchester Stadium providing staff with world- class facilities and equipment. Known as City@ Home, and built at a cost of £2.1 million, the new MCFC offices were 95 percent locally made and sourced, providing a significant boost to the local economy. n In 2009-10, more than £2 million has been invested in improving the training facilities at Carrington, new accommodation and pitches for the MCFC Academy and the establishment of a new medical centre and gym for all of our players. More than 60 percent of the work and materials for these important infrastructure projects were provided by local suppliers. n In 2009-10, the MCFC retail store, box office, award-winning media suite and executive boxes have all been improved at a cost of over £3 million, with more than 90 percent of the work and materials provided by local suppliers. These investments have enhanced the Club’s revenue generating potential while improving the matchday experience for partners, media and supporters. Manchester City Football Club Annual Report 2009/10 FOUR. Commercial and Operational Excellence 49/50
